comment.text: This protein is the basis of the ABO blood group system. The histo-blood group ABO involves three carbohydrate antigens: A, B, and H. A, B, and AB individuals express a glycosyltransferase activity that converts the H antigen to the A antigen (by addition of UDP-GalNAc) or to the B antigen (by addition of UDP-Gal), whereas O individuals lack such activity.
Membrane-bound form in trans cisternae of Golgi. Secreted into the body fluid.
The conserved DXD motif is involved in cofactor binding. The manganese ion interacts with the beta-phosphate group of UDP and may also have a role in catalysis.
The soluble form derives from the membrane form by proteolytic processing.

Genetic variations in ABO define the ABO blood group system [MIM:616093]. The ABO blood group system is the most important blood group system in blood transfusion. The sequence shown here is that of the A transferase. The B form differs by a few residues substitution. Residues 266 and 268 are important for specificity. The O phenotype results from a single base frameshift in the N-terminal extremity of the gene, resulting in a severly truncated protein without catalytic activity.

feature.description: Helical; Signal-anchor for type II membrane protein
In allele Aw08 and allele Bw08; dbSNP:rs7853989.
In allele Bel01; loss of manganese binding and reduced catalytic activity.
In group B transferase; lower-level protein expression and intracellular cytoplasmic mislocation.
In allele A106 and allele B3.
Alters substrate specificity so that both UDP-N-acetyl-D-galactosamine and UDP-galactose are utilized.
Alters substrate specificity of group B transferase.
Decreases specific activity of group B transferase almost to zero.
